title: Syllabus
text: This is an introductory course to the principles of data visualization and their applications with R. Topics include: the role of graphics in a data analysis project, the grammar of graphics and its implementation with ggplot2; the use of analytical patterns/tasks to choose the right kind of graphic; understand common color models and their relationship to human vision; use of color with tools such as the color wheel, color schemes, color pickers, and color palettes; designing principles (e.g. data-to-ink ratio, good practices, visual perception); assessment of graphics (what makes a graphic good); animated and interactive graphics; shiny apps (time permitting).

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Outcomes
At the end of the course, students will be able to:

Explain the importance/need of visualizing data
Describe the framework of the grammar of graphics for creating plots
Use functions from ggplot2 and other packages for making graphics in R
List five or more of the analytical patterns/tasks (proposed by Stephen Few) for choosing the right graphic
Specify colors through the use of a color model, and its hexadecimal syntax
Demonstrate an adequate encoding of data with color
Recognize color schemes when inspecting a graphic
Assess the effectiveness of a graphic intended for reporting/communicating purposes
Apply and/or suggest changes that increase the data-to-ink ratio of a graphic
Produce animated charts as well as graphics with interactive element

title: Syllabus
text:
Pre-requisites:
Because our main computational tool is R (and RStudio), it is desirable to have taken or be currently enrolled in a course in which you got an introduction to R (e.g. STAT 20, 33A, 33B, 133, or PB HLTH 142). It is also nice to have some previous experience analyzing data.

title: Syllabus
text:
Methods of Instruction
We will be using a combination of materials such as slides, tutorials, sample scripts, reading assignments, live demos, and chalk-and-talk. In-class attendance is mandatory.
The main computational tool will be the computing and programming environment R. The main workbench will be the IDE RStudio.

title: Syllabus
text:
Recommended Readings
The following books are not required, but will be referenced throughout the course for slides, assignments, and more:

 Data Visualization  by Kieran Healy.
 Geocomputation with R  by Robin Lovelace, Jakub Nowosad, and Jannes Muenchow.
 Now You See It: Simple Visualization Techniques for Quantitative Analysis  by Stephen Few.
 Effective Data Visualization (2nd edition): The Right Chart for the Right Data  by Stephanie Evergreen.
 R for Data Science  by Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund.

Late Policy
Everyone starts with 9 slip days. That is, if for any reason you are not able to turn in an assignment on time, you will automatically be charged one slip day for each extra day the assignment will take you. If you have no slip days left, you may ask your instructors for additional slip days. Notice:

You may not use more than 4 slip days for one assignment.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Cooperatively
With the obvious exception of quizzes, we encourage you to discuss all of the course activities with your friends and classmates as you are working on them. You will definitely learn more in this class if you work with others than if you do not. Ask questions, answer questions, and share ideas liberally.

title: Syllabus
text:
Academic Honesty
Cooperation has a limit, however. You should not share your code or answers directly with other students. Doing so doesn’t help them; it just sets them up for trouble. Feel free to discuss approaches to the problems with others, but you must write your own solutions. Please complete your own work and keep it to yourself. If you suspect other people may be plagiarizing you, let us know ASAP. For more information please read the Honor Code Guide for Syllabi.
We expect you to do your own work and to uphold the standards of intellectual integrity. Collaborating on homework is fine and I encourage you to work together—but copying is not, nor is having somebody else submit assignments for you. Cheating will not be tolerated. Anyone found cheating will receive an F and will be reported to the Center for the Student Conduct.
If you are having trouble with an assignment or studying for an exam, or if you are uncertain about permissible and impermissible conduct or collaboration, please come see me with your questions. Rather than copying someone else’s work, ask for help. You are not alone in this course! The course staff is here to help you succeed. If you invest the time to learn the material and complete the projects, you won’t need to copy any answers.

title: Syllabus
text:
Special Accommodations
Students needing accommodations for any physical, psychological, or learning disability, should speak with me during the first two weeks of the semester, either after class or during office hours and see the dsp website to learn about Berkeley’s policy. If you are a DSP student, please contact your instructors at least three weeks prior to a midterm or final so that we can work out acceptable accommodations via the DSP Office.
For relevant DSP accommodations that provide occasional extensions on assignments, we may provide a two-day extension as long as you contact us before the assignment is due. More details about these consideratinos may be discussed with the DSP staff.
If you are an athlete or Cal band member, please check your calendar. Do not take the class if you are not available to take the midterms, and/or attend lab discussions. I won’t be able to provide accommodations for an early or late exam.

title: R and RStudio
text:
In data visualization, there are many options out there in terms of coding languages. Fortunately, the foundational principles of effective visualization remain consistent for all of them. Subsequently, our class will center its focus on R, and utilize RStudio as our chosen IDE.
If you don’t already have R and RStudio, you can click here to find download links for both.
If you’re having trouble getting set up, feel free to email your instructors about the issue.
